snippet: The tiny village of Babanakayama, Japan, had plans to build a road to resettle on higher ground, but opposition has sidelined the project.
abstract: Plans to rebuild tiny Japanese village Babanakayama on higher ground following 2011 tsunami have stalled, deepening uncertainty for its 370 mostly aged residents; roadblocks to effort include scarcity of flat land, wrangling over prices and reluctance of population to consolidate into centralized communities; difficulties help explain why nearly 10 months after the tsunami, few villages and towns along coastline have succeeded at relocating.
lead_paragraph: The tiny village of Babanakayama, Japan, had plans to build a road to resettle on higher ground, but opposition has sidelined the project.

headline.seo: In Babanakayama, Japan, Road to Future Leads Nowhere
headline.main: In Tsunami Aftermath, ‘Road to Future’ Unsettles a Village
headline.print_headline: In Tsunami Aftermath, ‘Road to Future’ Unsettles a Village
